properties.title: IDEAS TO BE BRAINSTORMED FOR SOLUTIONS TO THE BP OIL SPILL AND THE FUTURE.
properties.description:
A hinged cofferdam can be placed around the  BOP. Hinged, so it doesn’t interrupt present operation. (Alternately, a notched clam shell type shovel concept could be brainstormed and utilized). Close hinge with flap to loosely seal seam.  Tall enough to intercept above the oil leak with no bottom (sits on seafloor after closing and with a top with big notch for loose fit around the BOP and cap. Have port in side with variable speed pump to feed liquid to surface. Speed up pumping action to point where there is neutral or  minimal negative or positive  pressure on the containment container. Pump oil to surface to recovery vessel. Use same precautions and concepts to prevent hydride formation.


How To Cut The Drilling Interception Time/depth


I believe one can shorten well drilling intercept time by a significant amount by additions to/or changes in the drilling plan. Part of the procedure will prevent further casing blowouts and reduce the depth required to inject the one million, one hundred thousand pound column of mud (actually, only the 9 5/8” diameter portion X 13,000 feet) above the reservoir to counteract hydrostatic pressure, estimated by some at 13,000 psi from the reservoir. With the use of a mud with an overall density of 5.85 instead of 1.67 as is required for a 13,000 foot column, the higher density can be achieved by using depleted uranium powder and as only a 25% component of the mix, the column can be reduced to 3,600 feet in length from 13,000 feet. Combining this with chloroform, a dense fluid, (1.489 specific gravity vs. water at 1.0)  instead of water, would further increase the mud density and required column length of mud. With lead substituted for depleted U, the column length required is still only 5,500 feet long. Again, only a static pressure head is active (~ 13,000 psi ). Change mud composition slowly as proceed with injection. Have interceptor well approach the target well at a vertical upward angle to bring into play the Venturi effect to assist in pushing mud into the well.  With the oil not moving, then an additional amount of the mud mixture designed specifically for this purpose can be injected into the well-slowly- to provide an increase in the safety margin for balancing downward pressure until cement can be added to seal the well.  

For the mud liquid carrier, Chloroform is produced in nature and is liquid at room temperature, and pressure and which by itself has a higher density than some mud’s (1.489 gm/cc) but its density characteristics with  pressure and temperature, and the earth’s thermal gradient (~+75 degrees Fahrenheit/ mile of depth) may not make it the best candidate for the carrier fluid. Identify the best one by brainstorming. Also, as noted, the solid portion should be looked at under these circumstances where cost is no object, i. e. lead, @11.83g/cc or after an initial injection of lead mud as a buffer, depleted uranium at ~ 19.07 g/cc or a combination.  All of these materials are readily available and safe to use if handled properly. Also, consider adding different chemicals to the water/chloroform that are soluble in them and heavy or may react to form purposeful hydrates, in the presence of methane etc. 

Continuation Of Summary

The BP oil spill is not being handled in a professional and logical manner. In addition to reducing the depth for the interceptor well, the technical problems that could have been identified early on at the blow out protector (BOP) on the sea floor to totally stop the flow of oil are described. Then, how each of these problems could have been met with proper brain-storming techniques. Next, how BP seems to have missed the boat on some of these aspects. Then an overview of some equipment or procedures to address these technical problems. Then some bells and whistles one should include on one equipment concept. Then a critique of some of the deficiencies I have identified in BP’s work based on information I have read and TV reports  and BP write-ups and videos I have seen. Then some second guessing and what might have been. Then, problems with BP’s approach to this specific problem. Next, what an oil company’s philosophy might be for moving forward and what can the US government do to more proactively work toward more quickly finding solutions to the spill.  Lastly, my credentials for making these statements. 

* * indicates the idea under discussion can be expanded and/or additional ideas, examples or concepts can be provided by the author.




The drilling depth to intercept is based on the height of the mud column needed to balance the static and dynamic oil pressure. Instead use the drilling records for drill speed, rock density etc to determine the safe depth below which there is no concern for case integrity in the event a rupture of the casing has taken place. * *

 One other point. If I can come up with a basis for drilling to a shallower depth (time) for interception, others may have too- with even better suggestions. Has BP started a shallow interception well as a backup and for redundancy? They need to.



Some Concerns Regarding The Present Design Of The BOP.

Having heard that the well casing may have failed when mud was injected under high pressure, who can say that it might or might not have failed if the BOP had been activated and it performed as planned? Oil would be leaking into the seabed without any indication of failure. 


OVERVIEW

Needless to say. No, maybe it does need to be said. The people who are responsible for this program to date have not exhibited the proper amount of caution when making decisions until only very recently. They apparently have taken the magnitude of the event as an indication that they must bow to public pressure and get something done- even if it turns out to be only partially effective or wrong. Use caution. Listen. Test where possible. Use actual models, not just computer ones. Brainstorm properly. In my experience as a researcher these are critical to a true understanding of what is going on.

Technical Problems.
 
1.	From before the start, BP should have had a plan. From the start BP should have been thinking about putting in place a system on the ocean floor that would be anchored and allow easy positioning of objects they brought down to the BOP, the blow-out preventer. An anchored incrementally movable cable system of some sort with sensors. Or like a frame that is like the female part of a socket so that once in place, new containment equipment could be easily positioned.  Also, samples of oil and venting gas to calculate gas fraction, determine oil density, chemical characteristics, particle content, particle hardness, friability, compressability, flow characteristics, corrosion characteristic, etc. The latter may have been done but how soon? Then when they formed, an analysis of the hydrates. More on this later. In other words, there should have been an emergency plan in place before drilling began to quickly provide direction and have in place or at least on hand material, people and assignments in the event of a disaster. There obviously wasn’t a good one.
2.	The major problem should not have involved trying to siphon off part of the flow of oil. The major problem is stopping the flow.
3.	Re sawing off the tube, which could have ended up being a disaster. As any woodsman knows, hollow wood branches or even solid ones are going to most likely pinch the blade unless you stabilize the branch or pull it apart as you saw. A laser or welding torch approach would probably have been better. BP may have been lucky they were able to fully make the cut with the shear.* *
4.	One needs to place something over/ around/ under or in the emitting tube or physically reduce the size of the opening to be able to slow and then stop the oil flow in a controlled manner. 
5.	BP hasn’t to date totally addressed the problem of how do you get a cap on the oil when it is coming out at a pressure to produce a flow rate of  over six hundred and forty thousand gallons of oil a day (7 ½ gallons per second) from a column that is a couple of miles long/tall. Plus millions of cubic  feet of gas It is like a kid trying to place a closed nozzle on a flowing garden hose. So they ended up opening up the nozzle and managed to physically hold a  leaky “miss-threaded” cap in place but they now have to siphon a portion off. Knowing they might be successful in capturing large amounts of oil, why didn’t they have that capacity in place on standby?   Who is involved in logistics?
6.	They still haven’t really put the cap on the tube, they have just moved the capping location away from the BOP head. 
7.	The problem here is static pressure  (momentum or dynamic pressure is minimal). One has to realize that that several mile long column of incompressible oil pressure needs to be addressed slowly. One cannot go to zero or negative velocity instantly. It has to be done slowly. An analogy is “How do you catch a speeding bullet? ”You surely don’t put your hand over it and try and stop it.” I heard on TV earlier that literally thousands of gallons of mud were forced down the tube at high pressure and rate in the “top kill” exercise. And then the procedure was quickly shut down due to something being amiss. I heard an earlier BP video where the Engineer in charge bragged about their high pressure/high volume capacity for this exercise. Under the pumping conditions described, the friction effects and the long column of uncompressible oil  and compressed gas, raised the pressure in the tube to the point apparently where it exceeded the rupture strength of the drill pipe casing along a portion of the pipe. I do not understand how this could be allowed to happen, but it apparently did. This concept is taught in freshman Statics. A basic Mechanical Engineering exercise. 
8.	The solution then is to fit some kind of device around or in the pipe that may leak at first and that doesn’t restrict the flow in any way and then by increments, fix the leak(s)…. 
9.	and eventually address the main flow out of the tube in such a way that the size of the flow stream is made smaller and smaller until it is finally cut off. And monitor the pressure and don’t let it exceed the critical value. 
10.	Obviously, it is important to monitor other important factors so one can slow down or adjust procedures in the event the system becomes unstable.
11.	How might it become unstable? For example, if the equipment exceeds its pressure rating or if it were to shift allowing oil to flow out of new leaks created by the shift. 
12.	It is important to have overkill and redundancy built into the equipment and sensors. 
13.	 It is important to have a method of capturing or reducing the size of leaks in a controlled systematic manner that the flow of oil at high pressure, velocity and volume has negligible impact on the process as it proceeds. In other words we don’t want to try and cap the oil we want the oil pressure to help, not hinder the process of slowing then stopping the oil flow if at all possible. The system needs to be stable, once it is in place, and not move. This can be done in stages.
14.	The system needs to have methods of introducing “mud” and cement to the desired locations and at the proper time to eventually cap the well.


What might have been proposed before BP began their poorly conceived and exercised capping concept is the following:

Equipment. 

If the well pipe extending out of the BOP has not been cut too short, drill small holes for inserting pressure and velocity gages. Then place a swagger over the end of the pipe and slowly swage it closed using a pointer swagger. The swagger will not interfere with the oil stream and as the tube is concentrically swaged, the flow and pressure can be monitored. Further, the wall thickness will increase as swaging proceeds so that the danger for rupture or expansion at this location will decrease as swaging proceeds.  However, it appears to be too short even for this. If longer, a conventional tube swagger might have been used. The swagger would have to be pressurized of course and pneumatically operated. Too bad this contingency wasn’t allowed for.* *

BF Deficiencies.

I have only watched a couple of BP’s video’s. And a couple of updates, They really don’t get it. There has been no sense of urgency. From the president on down. The words sometimes aren’t even right. The president wants everyone to see that he is on top of everything. He isn’t. The “This  is the first time this has been attempted at a mile underwater” is of no importance. If BP had had a real tested plan and had thought ahead working at these depths would be old hat. BP stated they are working with the smartest brains in America. The experts in their fields. I see several things wrong. Their list of experts is apparently outdated and they have not picked  all of the right fields of expertise. Also, their experts either have big egos and can’t work together or they have poor leadership. I assume the latter.  I have seen no evidence of their brainpower until recently when vents were discussed and a legitimate cautious tone was taken following the “Top Kill” attempt. 

I saw the BP video with the white box. Actually I think it had been gotten from another shallow water project. It had to be painted white I guess so it could be seen. How long does it take to find it and get it to the site? Does it take a day or more to let it dry?  Then when it failed because of hydrates plugging up the “siphon tube” it was set aside on the sea floor.  So if they decide they need it again they will have to bring it up to modify it. Hydrates. Plugging.  Isn’t this what one eventually wants to do? So, can you enhance the effect and make it happen so much it reduces the oil flow and potentially even stops it until the interceptor drilling does it’s job?  Can one use an analysis of the hydrates to add to the seawater around the box, or if they had thought to place ports in the box, inject hydrate material directly into the box so the solution is supersaturated? I also heard from the chief engineer that the seawater around the box was about 30 degrees, below freezing for fresh water, but above it for seawater and they were using methanol to reduce hydrates. Two things. What would injecting or blanketing fresh water around the box do? Would it make ice? Would pumping liquid nitrogen to or into the box freeze even seawater or make the hydrate formation even “better”? Certainly it might make the oil more viscous. I heard brainstorming was done and explained after a reporters question re golf balls and tire pieces and towels. It was acknowledged that that was what was going to be used. So they could then inject mud that would stay put. “Top Kill”. First off, that is a poor excuse for brainstorming.* * My first thoughts off the top were metallic Velcro, Velcro with both hooks and loops on every piece. Then that box that is sitting on the seafloor could have all kinds of hooky catchy things welded to the inside. So as they injected material they would get caught onto it. Then treble fish hooks. Then why release stuff into the box without holding on to it and being able to move it up and down in the oil stream. So go fishing with hooks on a cable. With bobbers and vanes in order to direct them. Then umbrellas to open up in the oil flow. All attached to cables? Then Velcro covered bucky balls.  Then a scrap yard electro-magnet attached to the box, or several and inject iron objects which would be held in the box. And on and on.

Another thing that was particularly disturbing was the answer to the question about help from people outside BP. Something like yes, we have gotten thousands of suggestions but of course we have thought of most of them. A typical NOT INVENTED HERE answer. How could anyone have a solution better than ours? We are the experts. On brainstorming one should encourage answers, not discourage them. Very poor PR too. * *

Second Guessing. What Might Have Been Done.

Isn’t it criminal to have a system so complicated and expensive that you can’t afford to test it and provide instructions that TWO upper management people must “Push the Button”? And have something that could fail? And did with no backup? Even in spite of warnings? Why wasn’t management looking for a better system? A system that was simple, not costly to test periodically and had some redundancy. A non ‘all or nothing’ system? I think I know what that system is but why don’t they? * * At the least why didn’t someone think about what would happen under the conditions where a blowout could occur. As it did. How could this disaster have been minimized and lives saved?

Simple.

THE REASON THE PLATFORM SANK AND PROBABLY LIVES WERE LOST IS BECAUSE THE FIRE WAS FUELED WITH OIL FROM THE WELL AND PIPE TO THE PLATFORM.  IF THAT PIPE HAD BEEN SEVERED, AUTOMATICALLY, ON RECEIVING THE SIGNAL FROM A SENSOR THERE WOULD HAVE BEEN NO FUEL TO FEED THE FIRE. AND IF A CONTAINMENT DEVICE HAD BEEN IN PLACE AROUND THE WELL-HEAD THERE WOULD BE NO OIL SPILL TO SPEAK OF. AND, EVEN AFTER THE FIRE STARTED, THERE WERE TWO+ DAYS BEFORE THE PLATFORM  SANK * *

Problems With BP’s Approach to This Specific Problem.

The main problem I find with BP’s approach is they placed no or little value on anything except money when they didn’t have to. Everything we have seen is all a façade. Image. Image. Image. No real integrity. They don’t really know what they are doing as it has nothing to do with the routine job of oil drilling but they would like our government and the public to think they do. 



Philosophy.

I worked at Alcoa when Paul O’Neal was President. He set as a goal for everyone in the company the goal of safety and being a good community neighbor. And he meant it. He fired a VP once who allowed a site to become polluted and he also made sure that every accident or near miss was autopsied. And a correction was made so that it couldn’t happen again. And accident rates dropped and continue to drop. I heard Rand Paul has said that the BP incident was an accident. It wasn’t With BP’s set of priorities. It was bound to happen sooner or later. It didn’t need to happen but it did. An indication it was going to, was the number of violations found in the BP Texas refinery disaster. I understand more than 50 times the next highest number recorded by a competitor. Who is to blame for all of this? In my mind the first to blame is the president of BP. The second is the board who hired him. On moving forward I would like to see every oil company held accountable to standards of safety that are moving targets and require ongoing commitments of money and resources to safety and environmental protection including research programs that address prevention and better, faster and more complete cleanup solutions. And not just mechanical devices but other off the wall approaches including dispersant development and testing, microbe testing, where the oil goes, how to recapture it and so on. And the oil company pays out of their oil profits. 

What Can The US Government Do To More Proactively Find Solutions To The Spill?  

I have been in research all of my professional life. It is disappointing to me to see some aspects of basic research being conducted in an esoteric fashion such that to find a practical use is below the researcher. For example, if one is working in a high purity metal system, isn’t it more practical to work in a system that allows the results to be used by the companies production divisions who in both the short term and long term financially support the research? There is a lot of research being conducted under the sponsorship of the US government that could be pointed toward finding solutions to many of the environmental problems the gulf faces. And it might be beneficial to us all to have the government place incentives on certain area’s of effort.  
Also, we have a new energy resource that has just been identified to have reserves that will last decades. I believe the government should mandate use of shale natural gas in vehicles and for other energy requirements where it can be substituted for oil and oil bi-products, I have numerous other thought regarding the cleanup but this too long already.  * * Also, about a better BOP system.  * *  I’d be happy to talk about any of this.

Finally as part of a restitution plan use income tax statements to determine prior income related to anything that has been curtailed by the spill and have BP fund a fraction of this money back to affected citizens.
 
I hope this information is communicated by you and others to other people with the where-with-all to make things happen. I believe this paper identifies some of the real problems that have not been addressed and contains practical solutions that can be implemented quickly and perhaps will provide guidance to prevent further problems.



Credentials.

I am a retired PhD in Metallurgical Engineering with minors in Mathematics and Physics. I spent my entire career in research including a short stint at Alcoa’s ATC as Division Manager of Fabrication Technology. I retired as VP of Research for a small aluminum company. I have over twenty patents. 

Sincerely,  

Bill Setzer 
wcsetzer@gmail.com
859-391-2431

APPENDIX

 Total Leak Stoppage Instead Of Capture

Early on, this might have been feasible.

1.	A  short cylinder big enough to fit around the three stage cylinder which fits around the BOP to act as a cofferdam. 
2.	Steel or lead or depleted uranium  shot to “ hold in any mud or ‘cement.’” This will be placed inside the cofferdam. 
3.	A three part cylinder that fits fairly snuggly around the BOP and has a tapered upper section that is designed to fit and seat around the tube to minimize oil flow down around the tube as is presently being exhibited in the underwater videos we see from BP.  The lower part of the three part cylinder fits inside the cofferdam and the upper portion extends above the tube from which the oil is emitting. 
4.	The lower stage fits down into the cofferdam and about 2/3 the way up the BOP and is fitted with numerous hydraulic cylinders facing inward up and down and around the circumference of the lower portion of the three stage cylinder that can be activated slowly in tandem from four or more points of the compass, north, south, east, west at once. This is so that the overall cylinder can be mechanically stabilized by pushing from all sides on the BOP. 
5.	A schematic of the BOP should be used to determine which hydraulic cylinders to active first as there are welded on pipes and flanges on the BOP. This is in order to prevent shifting of the three stage cylinder during activation of the hydraulic cylinders. 
6.	At the top of the lower section are baffles that directs any oil that is leaking around the tube toward the openable and closable vents that are around the periphery of stage two of the three stage cylinder. They start out open.  They are of a size to minimize any back pressure. At the juncture between section one and two there is a “rubber” gasket that prevents the majority of the oil from going down into the lower section so that this lower section is filled either with seawater or oil that is relatively stagnant. There are ports in the lower section so that first mud and then a catalytic cement can be injected at the appropriate time to fill the lower portion of the cylinder. 
7.	Once the cylinder is in place and the hydraulic cylinders have been activated inward, shot will be placed between the lower part of the cylinder and cofferdam to act as a partial seal. Then enough mud will be injected to complete the seal and finally the cement will be added to complete the stabilization of the three part cylinder. The shot may be mixed with small pieces of cellophane or rubber balloons etc. to enhance the seal. The cement will also provide additional stability to the cylinder as there are protrusions from the BOP and provide redundancy in the event one or more of the hydraulic cylinders fails with time. There will be stresses placed on the cylinder during the final stage of reducing flow from closing the upper portion of the tube that need to be addressed. 
8.	Once the cement has set and the cylinder is stable motion wise, it will be time to close the vents in the middle section of the cylinder. At this point there will be no motion of the oil although it may be under some elevated pressure due to any friction conditions that exist concerning the upper portion of the cylinder. Once the vents are closed, in the second section, a valve in the second section can be activated and the same type of cement as used before can be employed to fill stage two of the cylinder under high pressure, further stabilizing the cylinder. 
9.	Once this cement has set up, work can begin on the third stage of the cylinder.
10.	The description of the third stage of the cylinder is simple. It is of simple design. Namely, it is a cylinder of perhaps almost no flair (remember the upper portion of stage two was tapered to provide a seated fit) then flairs out to one half to one inch clearance that extends maybe two to three inches to a foot beyond the end of the tube which is gushing oil. 
11.	On the end of the cylinder is a valve which is infinitely adjustable as to how open it is.  It should start fully open. When fully open it should provide no impingement on the oil flowing out of the tube. The thickness of the cylinder and welds material should provide a triple or more than usual safety factor for pressure based on fully annealed material. If possible the material should be thick enough that it won’t exceed it’s fatigue limit. If possible all material and welds should be stress relieved.  The valve(s) should be of such a design that the high pressure oil should not impede it’s operation. And it should be such that if the mechanical, hydraulic or electric closing operation should fail, it will slowly close automatically and provide a positive seal like a butterfly valve. However, if the calculated critical pressure for rupture is approached the closure should stop. For redundancy it may be desirable to have two or more of these in series in the event one were to fail. On the side of this third stage of the cylinder will again be incorporated high pressure inlet ports so that mud can be slowly pumped into the throat of the tube as needed to reduce the pressure followed by the appropriate cement to seal the well.    

Bells and Whistles

1.	Two adjustable crossing cables with load cells to hang across to the other side of the BOP so that loads can be monitored by tightening the cables. These could be placed such that the protrusions on the BOP act as anchor locations for the cables as they are tightened. The load cells would then alert one to any shifting of the three stage cylinder.
2.	Pressure gauges in each stage of the cylinder. 
3.	Stress gauges at numerous critical points on the cylinder.
4.	Quick snap easy release high pressure fittings. 
5.	Velocity meters in throat of third stage and elsewhere.
6.	Vibration meters to make sure no harmonics are set up.
7.	Independent non backward flow valves for the hydraulic cylinders.
8.	Position meters to positively identify the valve open amount and   position.
9.	Temperature sensors. 
10.	Mud sensors. 
11.	Cement sensors. Ultrasound?? Resistance meters?
12.	Further larger cylindrical cap to further encapsulate the total system to be filled with cement once the system is sealed.

properties.title: Dead sperm whale in Gulf of Mexico
properties.description:
NOAA Conducts Tests to Determine Fate of Whale Found Dead in Gulf of Mexico
Whale Not Found in Oiled Water, but Cause of Death Unknown


On Tuesday, June 15, the NOAA Ship Pisces reported a dead sperm whale floating 77 miles due south of the Deepwater Horizon spill site. NOAA is currently in the process of conducting thorough testing to determine the circumstances surrounding the mammal’s death, as well as collect information about its life. This is the first dead whale reported since BP’s rig exploded on April 20. It was not found in oiled waters; however, its location of death is unknown.

As soon as the whale was sighted, Pisces Field Party Chief Paul Felts called the marine mammal hotline to report the finding to the Wildlife Branch of the Unified Command and NOAA’s marine mammal experts.


Based on the estimated size of the whale, scientists believe it is a sub-adult. Its condition suggests it may have been dead for between several days to more than a week. Although it was not found in oiled water, NOAA marine mammal experts are using hindcasting analysis to look into the location from which the whale carcass may have drifted.

While it is impossible to confirm whether exposure to oil was the cause of death, NOAA is reviewing whether factors such as ship strikes and entanglement can be eliminated. Samples collected from this carcass will be stored under proper protocols and handed off when the Pisces comes to port on July 2, or possibly if another boat is sent to meet the Pisces. Full analysis of the samples will take several weeks.

In accordance with the Wildlife Branch protocols, NOAA’s Southeast Regional Marine Mammal Stranding Coordinator Blair Mase requested that the NOAA field crew take photographs of the approximately 25-foot whale, collect skin swab for oil analysis, collect blubber and skin samples for analysis, and measure its height in the water. Although the whale is very decomposed, the photographs and samples will help scientists better understand how long it has been dead. The blubber and skin samples will be used for genetic analysis and to determine the sex of the animal. Measurements of the whale floating in the water will be used to determine how far and how fast it might have floated from where it died. The carcass has been marked so that aerial reconnaissance teams will be able to identify the individual and will not report it as a new mortality.

NOAA and the Unified Command Wildlife Branch have had numerous reports of sperm whales seen swimming in the oil, but this is the first confirmed report of a dead whale since the BP oil spill began. NOAA remains concerned about sperm whales, which are the only endangered resident cetaceans in the upper Gulf of Mexico. Sperm whales spend most of their time in the upper Gulf offshore area, live at depth in areas where subsurface dispersants and oil are present, and feed on deepwater squid, which may also be impacted by the oil and dispersants.

The NOAA Ship Gordon Gunter sailed yesterday for a multi-week cruise to do photo identification, assessments, tagging, biopsies, and prey-density studies for sperm whales and Bryde’s whales. Nearshore and offshore response efforts are continuing, and include investigations to determine cause of death or illness for dolphins that have stranded and aerial surveys for cetaceans throughout the area.  The information gained from these efforts will help assess the impacts of this event on cetaceans in the Gulf of Mexico.

properties.title: Health problems for my three-year-old
properties.description: My 3-year-old son was diagnosed with pneumonia on Monday morning. He was admitted to the hospital Monday afternoon and finally discharged Wednesday afternoon. He was a perfectly healthy and happy 3-year-old boy until this incident. I read that children have been susceptible to dispersant-related pneumonia. If this is true, I have a feeling that this was his problem, as he has had no significant health problems up to this point. He was in the hospital for three days, with the fourth day at home. I was, of course, by his side the entire time. Due to my being there with my son, I had to miss nearly a week of work.

properties.title: Whale sharks spotted near BP well, swimming in streamers of oil
properties.description:
Whale sharks, the huge fish that feed by vacuuming the sea surface, have been seen swimming between and through wide streamers of heavy oil a few miles from BP's spewing well in the Gulf of Mexico, a federal scientist said Thursday.

whale-shark-oil-spill-closeup.JPGEric Hoffmayer, University of Southern Mississippi Gulf Coast Research Laboratory via APA giant whale shark swims past a research vessel in the Gulf of Mexico, southwest of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill site. Research scientists are tagging the giant animals to study their fate in the wake of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill.

The three sharks did not appear distressed and their white-spotted hides were not visibly oiled, said Steve Gittings of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, who saw them on a flight Monday to locate oiled sea turtles for rescuers in boats.

"Don't get the picture that these looked like those pelicans you see photographs of," he said.
6
0
89Share

But oil can clog their gills and suffocate them as they swim at the surface, and they will swallow oil if they feed in it, said John Carlson, fisheries biologist in NOAA's wildlife section.

"They look like skimmer boats when they're feeding," Carlson said.

Gittings said the three whale sharks he saw, which he estimated at about 25 feet long, were about four miles from the sunken Deepwater Horizon, in an area where skimmer boats were slurping the heaviest oil.

"There's no continuous area of heavy oil. But there's so many streamers they couldn't avoid swimming through those streamers," he said.

The question now is how many of the creatures are dying in the oil, said Eric Hoffmayer of the University of Southern Mississippi's Gulf Coast Research Lab, who has studied whale sharks in the northern Gulf since 2002.

"Taking mouthfuls of thick oil is not conducive to them surviving," he said.

Hoffmayer has found that many of the northern Gulf's whale sharks feed off the mouth of the Mississippi River; the Deepwater Horizon site is about 40 miles southeast of the river.

"That basically confirms our worst fear: These animals do not know to stay away from the oil," Hoffmayer said.

Scientists on a teleconference Wednesday agreed there isn't any known way to make whale sharks swim away from oil, the way air cannon can be used to scare birds from airports, Gittings and Carlson said.

About all that can be done to protect them is make sure heavy oil is burned and skimmed from areas they might swim into, Carlson said.

They're easy to recognize; each is up to about 40 feet long and black with rows of white spots.

But there won't be any way to tell how many die. Sharks don't float.

"If they do die from the oil, they're going to sink to the bottom," Hoffmayer said.

whale-sharks-oil-spill-lots.JPGUniversity of Southern Mississippi Gulf Coast Research Laboratory via APMore than 100 whale sharks surround a research vessel in the Gulf of Mexico on June 21.

News of whale sharks in the oil came less than a week after a huge group was spotted elsewhere off the Louisiana coast where oil had not yet been found. One aerial photograph showed dozens of them.

"It blew my mind. There were probably more than a hundred sharks," Hoffmayer said.

The group seen June 21 was about 70 miles southwest of Port Fourchon, and about 60 miles from the western edge of the spill as shown on a federal map, he said.

Hoffmayer said it was hard to say whether the three seen Monday were from that group because the animals can travel more than 60 miles in a day.

"I've got a feeling that until whatever the food source they found disappears, they're not going to want to go," he said.

Nobody knows just how many whale sharks exist. They're on the World Conservation Union's "red list" of threatened species, but not on any U.S. list of threatened or endangered species. Federal law does ban killing them for sport or commercial use, Carlson said.

Hoffmayer said the animals can dive a mile deep, and could escape any effort to herd them away from the oil.

Last week's spotting came as part of a two-day excursion organized by the director of a documentary being filmed about marine biologist Sylvia Earle, founder of the Mission Blue Foundation.

Hoffmayer said four of the sharks were tagged.

By Janet McConnaughey, Associated Press writer

properties.title: Flu like symptoms and abnormal plant growth and brown spots with holes on bell peppers and tomatoes.
properties.description: For the last two weeks of June 2010 I have noticed abnormal plant growth in my tomatoes and bell peppers and banana peppers. My cucumbers start to form and then after each rain for the last two weeks of June the new cucumbers setting on just turn brown and shrivel up. I have taken pictures of the holes in the tomatoes and peppers and saved samples of the peppers and the deformed cucumbers.I have an upset stomach for the last 4 days which would be June 29-July 2. I also have headaches and a runny nose and then my nasal passages get dry and stuffy, also sneezing and tired all the time, no energy like before these most recent rains in central Florida.  I have been coughing up mucous and my chest feels irritated. My ears are stuffy, too. My ears are ringing, too. My skin has become oily and I rub off blackened skin from my neck to my chest and shoulders exposed to the outdoor elements. I feel lousy all over and wonder if the oil got in the rain and caused these things of late to happen. I wish I knew where to go on the internet to see what the VOC levels are for the methane being released in the Gulf from the BP oil spill on April 20. I am concerned my health has been affected by the chemicals coming from the BP Oil Spill in the Gulf of Mexico. I know others here have the same experiences with their plants and health. No one seems to have a website to show the monitoring levels of chemicals being released over Florida. Even the CDC does not report levels of the VOCs; only what the health risks of being exposed are to these chemicals. WHY? I am scared that we are getting exposed to poisoned chemicals here. Please help us. I want to leave this area soon. We wrote to Senator Nelson twice about these concerns last month and no response from him yet. Who can we turn to for help with these problems and concerns? Who is in charge to help the people, we need help! Please.

properties.title: Oil washed up on Comfort Island, St. Bernard
properties.description:
Oil spewing from the BP oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico has been spotted in several locations in St. Bernard Parish waters and crews were attacking it with skimmers, the parish said Friday.

21
0
25Share
BEACHREPORT070310.jpgView full size

Also, the parish's operations center was seeking the instruction from the Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries on handling the impacted rookeries and help from the agency in rescuing oil-soaked birds and other wildlife.

Reconnaissance activities over the past 24 hours showed the impact varies from tar balls to small and large patches of oil, the parish said. Oil has washed up on portions of the marsh and beach on Comfort Island, Brush Island, Curlew Island and portions of the Chandeleur Islands, the parish said.

Weather conditions allowed skimmers to go after the oil, the parish said. Also, 23 boats and 72 people were conducting boom reconnaissance and repair in the Chandeleur Islands, the parish said.

properties.title: Oil washed up on Curlew Island, St. Bernard
properties.description:
Oil spewing from the BP oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico has been spotted in several locations in St. Bernard Parish waters and crews were attacking it with skimmers, the parish said Friday.

21
0
25Share
BEACHREPORT070310.jpgView full size

Also, the parish's operations center was seeking the instruction from the Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries on handling the impacted rookeries and help from the agency in rescuing oil-soaked birds and other wildlife.

Reconnaissance activities over the past 24 hours showed the impact varies from tar balls to small and large patches of oil, the parish said. Oil has washed up on portions of the marsh and beach on Comfort Island, Brush Island, Curlew Island and portions of the Chandeleur Islands, the parish said.

Weather conditions allowed skimmers to go after the oil, the parish said. Also, 23 boats and 72 people were conducting boom reconnaissance and repair in the Chandeleur Islands, the parish said.

properties.title: Fort Morgan, 2-3 mile marker oil report
properties.description:
I have skipped a few days and will try to get up info on earlier dates soon. For now today: Oil washed up near the dune line in last week's overwash associated with Alex. Small tar balls and discoloration of the sand was present (see 1st two pics). The water was covered with a brown foamy scum which once on the beach dried into lines of brown scum (pics 3 & 4). Patchy weathered oil was present above above and below the high tide line along with oiled debris (pics 5-8). Some patches were large, some thick and beginning to be buried in the sand. All pics were taken between 30.22840N/87.98501W and 30.22890N/87.97886 Oil smell is present on the beach.

We now have a BP geologist and assistant assigned to monitor and protect wildlife on Ft. Morgan (hurray!) I discussed the situation at length with this scientist. She indicated that one problem is that the oil line is now so close to the dunes (in some cases over what she considers to be dunes)that vehicles involved in the monitoring and clean-up are forced to drive over the oil OR the dunes, neither of which is allowed. Vehicles driving over the dunes track oil up onto unoiled beach once they leave the oiled areas (pic #9). The same is true of people walking on the beach who walk through the oil (a number of people are doing so) and then track oil onto unoiled areas of the beach.

properties.title: Can smell chemicals in the air.
properties.description: For the past couple of weeks I have been able to smell and taste "something" in the air that isn't normal for this area.  The smell reminds me of insecticide, but it is too constant to be someone spraying for bugs.  Causes throat irritation and coughing, and the dogs don't even want to go outside.  This is almost every day, although there are some reprieves, perhaps due to the change in wind speed or direction.

properties.title: Texas Tarballs From Deepwater Horizon

properties.title: Severe headaches
properties.description: Beginning June 10th, I begain having severe headaches.  The pain was so intense, it made my blood pressure rise so high, that I became very ill.  My neurologist put me on heavy pain meds.  My skin is severly sllergic to benzene, which is the REASON I moved from the Milwaukee, WI area to Florida.  My skin was also badly breaking out, which is how I connected by headaches with toxic exposure.  We evacuated Florida on June 26th to Wisconsin. I have been steadily getting better since we arrived, and have only minor headaches, requiring only aspirin.  My skin has also cleared up.

properties.title: Tar balls reach Lake Pontchartrain
properties.description:
howing just how unpredictable and all-consuming the massive Gulf oil spill can be, tar balls and small sheens of oil have entered Lake Pontchartrain and are hitting Texas shores for the first time.

06rioletsMatthew Hinton / The Times-PicayuneMATTHEW HINTON / THE TIMES-PICAYUNE A tar ball washed ashore near the Treasure Isle subdivision in Lake Pontchartrain as people fish near the Rigolets in Slidell on Monday.

John Lopez, director of the Lake Pontchartrain Basin Foundation's coastal stainability program, spotted the first tar balls in the Rigolets Pass on Sunday. By Monday, the blobs of oil had washed ashore as far west as Treasure Isle in Slidell.
42
0
327Share

Cleanup crews used nets to scoop up the tar balls throughout the day, collecting more than 1,000 pounds of oil and waste. BP also deployed 19 manual skimming vessels and four decontamination vessels to the area, and placed 600-feet of hard and soft boom at a choke point in the Rigolets to prevent more oil from entering the lake. Cleanup efforts are expected to resume today.

Lopez said oil made its way into the lake because of winds from the far edges of Hurricane Alex last week as well as sustained east and southeast winds during the weekend. The winds from Alex pushed a large amount of oil into the Mississippi Sound for the first time, and the east winds during the past few days pushed oil into Lake Borgne, the Rigolets and eventually the eastern stretches of Lake Pontchartrain.

Wind patterns ultimately will decide the trajectory of oil, but Lopez said the general pattern of circulation in Lake Pontchartrain is counterclockwise, meaning if more oil came in the lake, it generally would travel along the north shore and then possibly loop back around to the south.

Although he expects the impacts from oil in the lake to be "pretty modest," Lopez acknowledged that there is a symbolism for the New Orleans area now that oil has reached the lake.

"It's kind of like it's coming to home now."

Citing the new reports of oil, the Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries on Monday issued precautionary fishing closures in parts of Lake Pontchartrain and in Lake Borgne, Lake St. Catherine, the passes and surrounding areas. The state's Department of Health and Hospitals also closed all oyster harvesting areas east of the Mississippi River, which includes Lake Borgne.

So far, the oil that has entered the Rigolets and the lake has been in small amounts and has been weathered greatly after traveling a long distance from the well site. The geography of eastern Lake Pontchartrain also has played a role in keeping most of the oil out, with narrow passes such as the Rigolets preventing a full flow from Lake Borgne and Mississippi Sound.

"It has a fairly tortuous route to get to the lake, and that's why we're at day 70-something of the spill, and we're just seeing the oil reach Lake Pontchartrain," Lopez said. "This oil we're seeing probably headed east toward Alabama and Florida before it came this way. It's traveled probably at least 100-200 miles, depending on how far east it went."

properties.title: 7 gallonsof tar balls collected on Bolivar Peninsula and Galveston Island
properties.description:
TEXAS CITY, Texas (AP) -- Tar balls from the Gulf oil spill found on a Texas beach were the first evidence that gushing crude from the Deepwater Horizon well has reached all the Gulf states.
GULF OIL SPILLAP Photo/ Hattiesburg American, Ryan MooreOil from the Deepwater Horizon oil spill along the beach in Pass Christian, Miss., on Sunday.

 

A Coast Guard official said on Monday that it was possible that the oil hitched a ride on a ship and was not carried naturally by currents to the barrier islands of the eastern Texas coast, but there was no way to know for sure.
24
0
26Share

The amount discovered is tiny compared to what has coated beaches so far in the hardest-hit parts of the Gulf Coast in Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and the Florida Panhandle. It still provoked the quick dispatch of cleaning crews and a vow that BP will pay for the trouble.

"Any Texas shores impacted by the Deepwater spill will be cleaned up quickly and BP will be picking up the tab," Texas Land Commissioner Jerry Patterson said in a news release.

The oil's arrival in Texas was predicted Friday by an analysis from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which gave a 40 percent chance of crude reaching the area.

"It was just a matter of time that some of the oil would find its way to Texas," said Hans Graber, a marine physicist at the University of Miami and co-director of the Center for Southeastern Tropical Advanced Remote Sensing.

About five gallons of tar balls were found Saturday on the Bolivar Peninsula, northeast of Galveston, said Capt. Marcus Woodring, the Coast Guard commander for the Houston/Galveston sector. Two gallons were found Sunday on the peninsula and Galveston Island, though tests have not yet confirmed its origin.

Woodring said the consistency of the tar balls indicates it's possible they could have been spread to Texas water by ships that have worked out in the spill. But there's no way to confirm the way they got there.

The largest tar balls found Saturday were the size of pingpong balls, while the ones Sunday were more like nickels and dimes.

Galveston Mayor Joe Jaworski said he believed the tar balls were a fluke, rather than a sign of what's to come.

"This is good news," he said. "The water looks good. We're cautiously optimistic this is an anomaly."

The distance between the western reach of the tar balls in Texas and the most eastern reports of oil in Florida is about 550 miles. Oil was first spotted on land near the mouth of the Mississippi River on April 29.

The spill is reaching deeper into Louisiana. Strings of oil were seen Monday in the Rigolets, one of two waterways that connect the Gulf with Lake Pontchartrain, the large lake north of New Orleans.

"So far it's scattered stuff showing up, mostly tar balls," said Louisiana Office of Fisheries Assistant Secretary Randy Pausina. "It will pull out with the tide, and then show back up."

Pausina said he expected the oil to clear the passes and move directly into the lake, taking a backdoor route to New Orleans.

The news of the spill's reach comes at a time that most of the offshore skimming operations in the Gulf have been halted by choppy seas and high winds. A tropical system that had been lingering off Louisiana flared up Monday afternoon, bringing heavy rain and winds.

Forecasters at the National Hurricane Center said there had been a 60 percent chance the system could blow into a tropical storm. But that was reduced later Monday to almost no chance because the storm had moved over land.

Last week, the faraway Hurricane Alex idled the skimming fleet off Alabama, Florida and Mississippi with choppy seas and stiff winds. Now they're idled by smaller storms that could last well into this week.

Officials have plans for the worst-case scenario: a hurricane barreling up the Gulf toward the spill site. But the less-dramatic weather conditions have been met with a more makeshift response.

Skimming operations across the Gulf have scooped up about 23.5 million gallons of oil-fouled water so far, but officials say it's impossible to know how much crude could have been skimmed in good weather because of the fluctuating number of vessels and other variables.

The British company has now seen its costs from the spill reach $3.12 billion, a figure that doesn't include a $20 billion fund for damages the company created last month.

The storms have not affected drilling work on a relief well that BP says is the best chance for finally plugging the leak. The company expects drilling to be finished by mid-August.

___

properties.title: Oil on wildlife and on shore
properties.description:
Fwd: Shoreline and Wildlife Impact in St. Bernard Parish, Evidence of Submerged Oil

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~




 
 

 



-----Original Message-----
From: Karen Bazile 
To: Karen Bazile 
Sent: Thu, Jul 15, 2010 9:20 pm
Subject: Shoreline and Wildlife Impact in St. Bernard Parish, Evidence of Submerged Oil



 





 
 
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE 
Thursday, July 15, 2010 at 9:00 p.m.
 
CONTACT:
Jennifer Belsom, Oil Disaster Public Information Officer
504-444-6249 or jbelsom@sbpg.net
Karen Turni Bazile, Executive Assistant to the President
St. Bernard Parish Public Information Officer
504-278-4280, 504-874-0980 or kbazile@sbpg.net
 
 
 
Shoreline and Wildlife Impact in St. Bernard Parish, Evidence of Submerged Oil


There were 31 oil sightings in St. Bernard Parish waters in the past 48 hours. Five of these sightings were on the water and 24 were shoreline or marsh impact. Several of these sightings included impact to wildlife with either oiled or deceased birds. Cleanup task forces were deployed to the Chandeluer Islands yesterday, which had confirmed shoreline impact. Rapid Assessment vessels with U.S. Coast Guard Pollution Investigators are working in cooperation with Air Operations, who will contact these vessels directly and immediately in the event of an oil sighting. Vessels are deployed to impacted areas to fortify these areas with hard and soft absorbent boom, and recovery vessels have also been deployed to these areas to assess impact and remediation activities. Skimming will be conducted where possible in these areas.   
 
There was an oil sighting on Tuesday that could not be confirmed by a pollution investigator, as it had apparently disappeared and could not be verified. There is now shoreline impact in the same area, a 100-foot long oiling near Point Lydia, evidence of submerged oil in parish waters. St. Bernard Parish President Craig Taffaro directed operations personnel to institute a program to track submerged oil. Local fishermen have begun constructing and deploying “sentinel snare booms,” which are snare or “pom pom” boom stretching from a buoy to an anchor, thus covering the entire water column, in anywhere from 6-foot to 12-foot depths. These snare booms are being placed 300 feet apart just outside of the Chandeleur Islands to detect how oil is getting into parish waters.
 
At the direction of President Taffaro, testing is being conducted this morning on existing technology to remediate oiled marsh. If this technology proves to be successful, operations will be able to use this process to begin cleaning oiled marsh areas in parish waters. 
 
###

properties.title: all Royal Tern chicks on Queen Bess Island appear to be dead and 30% adults heavily oiled
properties.description: Sadly, the Royal Tern chicks in the colony on Queen Bess all appeared to be dead.  They had survived for several weeks with fairly uniform oil on their feathers, but they did not survive the past week and a half.  In addition, about 30% of the Royal Tern adults now appear to be fairly heavily oiled.  However, they were still flying around and feeding.  It is unlikely that the adults could be rescued unless they become more heavily oiled, or unless they get very wet in a storm and become easier to capture.

properties.title: 130 birds killed by Gulf oil spill, 15 rescued in St. Bernard Parish found today
properties.description:
Louisiana's Department of Wildlife and Fisheries says oil from the Gulf spill has killed more than 100 birds in St. Bernard Parish.
oil-spill-feathers-nest.JPGRusty Costanza, The Times-PicayuneFeathers rest atop oil-stained marsh grass in Morgan Harbor in St. Bernard Parish on July 13.

Department official Robert Love said Tuesday that it's the first significant effect on wildlife in the parish behind the Chandeleur Islands, which were hit by the oil in early May.
0
0
0Share

Love said crews found about 130 dead birds and 15 live birds on Monday. Most were laughing gulls, with about four tricolored herons and a rail. He said the live birds included a roseate spoonbill.

Love said many of the birds were on Dry Bread Island, about 30 miles east of Alluvial City, or in Drum Bay, northeast of the island.

The area is east of Lake Borgne, and there's far more water than land.

Love said more crews were out Tuesday in the same area, but he didn't expect them to find as many oiled birds.

properties.title: Oiled dolphin's rescue ends in death
properties.description:
Christy Travis first saw oil splotched along the beach as she approached the surf at Fort Pickens. Then she turned and saw a bottlenose dolphin in distress.

“It was heartbreaking. Everyone was crying,’’ said Travis, 41, who was visiting with her family from Arkansas when they discovered the dolphin and joined with others in attempt to save it.

“We had oil all over us,’’ Travis said.

Thursday's photos

    * New reader-submitted photos from Pensacola Beach. »
    * AP's latest photographs from around the Gulf Coast. »
    * Tar balls wash ashore in Destin. »
    * Barges are readied in Destin. »
    * Click here to view photos of heavily oiled Pensacola Beach »
    * Check out the sand berms being set up at Grayton Beach »

The dolphin did not survive. It died while enroute to Gulf World Marine Park, a rescue facility in Panama City.

A necropsy will be performed to determine exact cause of death, according to Courtnee Ferguson of the BP Unified Command Joint Information Center in Mobile.

Once the dolphin was discovered, after beaching itself, a three hour ordeal ensued to try and save the mammal in the water. Two U.S. Coast Guard volunteers and a Florida Department of Environmental Protection officer were involved in the rescue attempt.

Travis said the dolphin was crying as people rushed to save it. She said people scraped oil off the dolphin with their hands.

“It was so sad. It just broke our hearts,” Travis said.

The dolphin’s struggle to survive added to the dismay of people stunned to find a mass of oil washing ashore and covering the pristine coastline at Fort Pickens.

This was the worst day for oil reaching Pensacola area beaches since the BP oil disaster began with an explosion April 20 off the Louisiana coast.

“It’s terrible. It’s awful,’’ said Dee Pittman, 57, a Pensacola resident, who was among the people gathered at Fort Pickens. “You can’t get close to the water. It’s (oil) just coming in. This is very dangerous.

“BP doesn’t get it. This is sacred ground to us. We got married on these shores. We baptized our children in this ocean. We entrust the ashes of our loved ones in this ocean.”

properties.title: 300-400 oiled pelicans on Racoon Island
properties.description:
Raccoon Island is the site of one of the state's largest colonial waterbird nesting colonies and a particularly important nesting area for brown pelicans. Last week, researchers from the Cornell Lab of Ornithology reported spotting at least 300-400 oiled pelicans on Raccoon Island, an area where government officials had documented only 68 oiled pelicans.

The difference in the numbers highlighted the counting method used by the government, which includes only oiled birds collected for rehabilitation or whose dead carcasses are collected to use as evidence in the spill investigation. Oiled birds in the many nesting areas that dot the Gulf coast typically are left in place and not counted in official tallies.

Marc Dantzker, one of the Cornell ornithologists, said efforts to protect the island with boom were insufficient. Raccoon Island is one of Louisiana's most important nesting grounds."There are more and more birds with oil on them," Dantzker said.

properties.title: Gulf Oil Disaster: 100 Days of Outrage: Friday July 30 PROTEST
properties.description:
Gulf Oil Disaster: 100 Days of Outrage: Friday July 30 PROTEST


 GULF OIL DISASTER [image: Gulf Bird Dying]
100 Days of Outrage!
Demands 100 Actions!
….Cities, Towns, Communities… Globally - because the environment has no
borders!
Friday, July 30th 2010
*Because* the oil gusher may not be capped
*Because* 100-200 million gallons of oil & 2 million of dispersants still
foul the Gulf
*Because* wetlands, shores, wild and marine life are still threatened
*Because* peoples' health still isn't protected
*Because* the truth is still not out
*Because* oil companies and government still want to "drill, baby, drill"
*Because* we're not stopping until the well is sealed and the Gulf is healed

•    Hang banners

Disaster

world the people's response is headline news.)

tolerable! surprise us!

properties.title: Oil Reclamation Unit
properties.description:
Oil Reclamation Unit

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Have patented a new oil reclamation unit ( skimmer ) will be in Louisiana in 36 hours, can skim large amounts of oil in less than 3 feet of water.

properties.title: Oil in bay grassess
properties.description: Soundside, Pensacola Beach, FL grasses in small inlet cove covered in thick oil

properties.title: Laid off workers at DuLac shrimp processing factory
properties.description:
A woman who has worked at Lafitte Frozen Foods (shrimp processing) for 10 years was laid off because of fishing closures. The only work that is being done at the processing plant is maintenance. She said that 20 women (many who are older) were the ones laid off because they primarily work the factory line. Some went to work for BP only because they need a way to support their family.

She said that, "they (BP) really have me in a touch place," as she had just bought a trailer which they are trying to repossess and she hasn't been able to pay her bills because she does not have money coming in.

properties.title: Shrimper out of work
properties.description:
A shrimper (who has shrimped his whole life) in Dulac told us that he is unable to shrimp because of the closures. Although there are a couple of spots that are open, all the good ones are shut down. August is when white shrimp season would have started and he would have been making upward of $7,000 a month instead of being paid by BP claims. He commented that her "would rather be out working that getting paid by them (BP)".

He shrimps in the few spots that are open because he has to feed his family. He says that he thinks it is strange some small areas are open because the boundaries are just barrier islands. When he shrimps in these places, the few shrimp that he nets go into a bucket, they put a light over them and can see an oil film/sheen (if this is the case they get dumped back in and shrimp processing factories do a double check).

He is unable to work for BP because of the size of his boat. Oyster beds are closed as well so he is unable to harvest oysters.

properties.title: Odors in Dulac
properties.description: Community member commented to us that sometimes they can smell petroleum odors at night in Dulac, but that it has become so normal, people are starting not to notice it and just accept it. She commented, "when you constantly live in it, you can't always tell what is normal and what isn't." Her sister-in-law who lives on Shrimper Row is 68 and has seen an increase in asthma since the spill happened.

properties.description: In Orange Beach, non-metallic sheen from Perdido Pass to Phoenix West is seen along the beaches to about two miles offshore. Also about three miles offshore is another patch of light non-metallic sheen south of Phoenix West.

properties.title: light sheen
properties.description: Back Bays of Orange Beach are clear of any surface oil. Just small amounts of light sheen from the booms near Boggy Point.

properties.title: non-metallic sheen
properties.description: In Gulf Shores, non-metallic sheen from west of State Park Pier to just west of Bon Secour Wildlife Refuge is seen along the beach to about 3 miles offshore.

properties.title: metallic sheen
properties.description: Twelve miles south of Dauphin Island and Fort Morgan is an area of heavy patches of brown-to-orange-like substance that has silver to metallic sheen. This substance is light surface oil. Looking further south is heavier sheen with possible surface oil as far as I could see from 12 miles offshore.

properties.title: BP outreach worker says there isn't as much work for cleaners
properties.description: BP workers getting laid off and BP outreach worker on Grand Isle said that its because there isn't much new oil coming ashore. Person came in looking for a job, angry about continuously getting the run around and BP telling him that he would have to be contracted through other groups and this was their answer to him- that there wasn't enough work. Are they kidding?

properties.title: Foul smell-sheen or dispersed oil?
properties.description: Bayou Chico in Pensacola, FL. We live on the bayou, and we now know BP has a cleaning station on the bayou. What are your thoughts on these pics? I have taken some pictures, and when I went to get a sample of the water, the oil looking substance you see in the pics.. dissipated to the point I wasn't able to see it. It seems to travel with the tides. I am very concerned and have had health issues as well. Irritated itchy eyes w/ discharge. Swelling, breathing issues, throat irritation, headaches, body aches, and rapid heart racing.

properties.title: Degraded oil in Mississippi Sound tests positive for dispersants, says lawyer
properties.description:
Lumpy, degraded oil collected in the Mississippi Sound has tested positive for several of the main ingredients in the Corexit dispersant used in connection with the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, according to scientists working for a New Orleans-based lawyer.

Officials with the federal government and BP PLC have maintained throughout the oil spill that no dispersant products have been used near shorelines in Alabama or Mississippi.  

“It is difficult to comment on testing conducted by third parties,” BP spokeswoman Dawn Patience wrote in an e-mail. “Throughout the response period, we have worked hand-in-hand and under the direction of the Coast Guard and EPA on the use of dispersants.”

Marco Kaltofen, part of the group of scientists who found the oil in Mississippi Sound, said it was impossible to determine when the dispersant had been applied to the oil. Results from the tests, which were conducted in a Colorado laboratory, indicated the oil was from the Deepwater Horizon well, he said.

“I consider this to be very interesting scientifically, as few samples detect dispersant, much less three of their major ingredients in the same sample,” said Kaltofen.

The material was collected by a group of scientists working for attorney Stuart Smith, who is representing the Louisiana-based United Commercial Fisherman’s Association and the Louisiana Environmental Action Network in a potential lawsuit regarding damage from the oil spill. The group found the oil about a mile north of Horn Island on Aug. 9.

“EPA samples found only one indication of dispersant near shore in Louisiana. That location was sampled several times with no other detection,” U.S. Environmental Protection Agency spokeswoman Terri White said in a Monday e-mail. “There is no authorization to apply any dispersant at this time. If anyone has information about this, they need to report it immediately so it can be investigated and referred to law enforcement.”

Jerry Moran, a New Orleans-based photographer who accompanied the group to document the sampling effort, said that the material looked unlike anything he’d seen during months of photographing the spill.

“We saw birds diving over a patch of oil. I’d never seen it that thick before. It looked like cauliflower. I had never seen it that texture before,” Moran said. “There was a rainbow sheen around us, a really thick, colorful sheen.”

Press-Register reporters encountered a similar material — strangely textured oil with a pronounced sheen — in Mobile Bay and Mississippi Sound several times in July and early August. The day before Moran’s group found the dispersant and oil mix, the Press-Register documented oil in a marsh on Horn Island.

BP and federal officials said that dispersants have not been used in the Gulf since July 19.

Smith, the lawyer who funded Kaltofen’s sampling expedition, discounted the notion that dispersants had not been used near shore.

“I personally saw C-130s applying dispersants from my hotel room in the Florida Panhandle. They were spraying directly adjacent to the beach right at dusk,” said Smith. “Fishermen I’ve talked to say they’ve been sprayed. This idea they are not using this stuff near the coast is nonsense.”

properties.title: Oil under the sand at Raccoon Island (link to video)
properties.description: In the headlines portion of LPB's weekly show last Friday (Aug. 27), Melanie Driscoll of the Audubon Society was on Raccoon Island August 20 and showed LPB's photographer hidden tar balls along the shore when you scratch just below the surface. Driscoll's story hits at about the 1:20 mark.

properties.title: Dead pelicans, gulls and fish on island near South Pass, LA
properties.description: Vessels of Opportunity fishermen are reporting dead birds (pelicans and gulls) have now been found in the same area as the fish kill reported to the map last week.  Now there are dead fish, dead birds surrounded by oil and dispersant mix indicated by brownish foam.  Many of the VOO fishermen have not been going out since the massive fish kill and now have been told that the operations south of Venice will be wrapping up and moving to Myrtle Grove.

properties.title: Petroleum and chemical odors affecting health and plants in Bradenton, FL
properties.description: A report came in to our office today from a woman in Bradenton, FL south of Tampa.  Her back door opens onto the Gulf of Mexico. She reports smelling petroleum and chemical odors whenever the wind blows from the west.  It is usually early in the morning when she gets these odors.  DUring the spill she had regular headaches which was unusual for her.  Now she is concerned about her plants and the trees in the area.  Many of them are browning and some of the trees are dying.  She saw them bounce back after the winter only to become sick again.  She attributes this to the spill.

properties.title: Since the oil spill, business at Madeira Beach Seafood is down 60 %
properties.description:
Madeira Beach, Florida - It's an 11-day commercial fishing trip that cost $7,000 in expenses and brought in 4,000 pounds of grouper.

But for the long-line grouper fishermen at Madeira Beach Seafood, it adds up to "an 11-day waste of time", to use the words of one fisherman.

Since the oil spill, business at Madeira Beach Seafood is down 60 percent.

Business managers blame the government's virtual shutdown of commercial fishing in the Gulf in the day after the spill, which led some Madeira Beach Seafood customers to look elsewhere. Many switched to buying seafood from Mexico and Central America.

And despite the fact that most of the long-line grouper fishing zones have reopened, things at Madeira Beach Seafood are getting worse.

"In the last few months, things have been deteriorating more and more. What we're seeing now is every month, it is getting progressively worse. We're hoping that in September, things will finally turn around," said Bob Spaeth, executive director of the Southern Offshore Fishing Association, Inc., which represents more than 100 fishermen in Madeira Beach.

Madeira Beach Seafood estimates its lost between $200,000 and $2 million since the oil spill.

So far, they haven't submitted a claim to BP on the advice of their lawyer and because they haven't finished tallying their losses.

In fact, Spaeth fears most of their losses will be future losses.

properties.title: Miles of Dead Fish in lower Plaquemines
properties.description: This is just a small glimpse of miles of dead rotting fish being ignored and dismissed by "BP" affiliates in lower Plaquemines Parish.Many types of fish are floating on the water off South Pass @ the mouth of the Mississippi River at (Garden Island).Surface "OIL" is also covering our waterways @ Main Pass and Passaloutre and there is oil creaping up Main Pass as I type this.I wish I had a photo of the oil but for some "mysterious reason" many boats were grounded today and my little pelican didn't make it to the scene.BP is telling us the oil is gone...Yeah right,ok,whatever you say!Are they wearing blinders instaed of safety glasses?BP is ignoring this and they expect our fisherman to do the same.We need these bayous and marshlands.The dispersants are killing our fish,and making the oil sink, SO IT'S NOT SEEN!Well,i guess it's time to spray again BP because it's surfacing!Our hired fishing boats are getting layed off but there's claenup to be done!!C'mon now...this is our way of life,our living,our future.Please,do something already!!!!!

properties.title: Air Quality- Toxicity Symptoms
properties.description: Within a couple of weeks after the oil spill, I was laying out in the sun by the swimming pool when I noticed unusual looking clouds, these clouds were like none I've ever seen before they had a pink halo and were tinged with an irradecent coloration. As the rain came I noticed pools of water tinged with the same colors like a rainbow of pastel oil. I did in fact notice a bad taste, that of chemicals for days after these episodes, I then discovered about BP spraying chemical dispursants in the air about the time that I developed a cough and and sinus infection I have had this since then and also I have noticed bruising under my nails and extreme dizzyness. I am sure this is some of the symptoms of the side effects of being exposed to these chemicals related to the oil spill. I have noticed many others coughing more than usual, too. I have been getting headaches and chestpain related to this but the worst thing is the dizzy feeling and nausea. I hope they stop spraying the codex, it's just making things worse for us humans and the sea life too.  Also, I observed some very odd Manatee behavior and I think they were sick, too.

properties.title: BP Oil Spill Health Emergency. Corexit Being Sprayed From Coast Guard Planes!
properties.description:
Dr. Chris Pincetich, Marine Biologist and Toxicologist, Project Gulf Impact, July 4, 2010:

    C-130 on "Oil Spill Cleanup"

    Transcript Excerpts

    Coast Guard planes are flying overhead at night spraying Corexit.

    You’re ask me if it’s getting on land, I’m telling you it’s getting sprayed on land.

    I know from my work with pesticide applications that even if you have a very good pilot the drift can be of concern.

    But the secondary effects are the kind of volatilization, evaporation and THEN movement.

    So, it’s applied, it sits on the surface, it comes on up a little bit, and then it moves around…

    Do i think there’s dispersant mixing with our everyday lives? Absolutely.
